value: caption=Excavated at Zeugma, the "Gypsy Girl" mosaic, thought to be depicting the earth goddess Gaia, is now in display at the Zeugma Mosaic Museum in Gaziantep.

Set in western reaches of Southeastern Anatolian plateau, Gaziantep is a surprisingly large (with a population of almost 2,000,000) and modern city.
. 15 km from city center. You can reach the city center from the airport with the Havaş shuttle service (9 lira, departs after most incoming flights)

) of the city is quite a few kilometers out of town. It is connected to city centre by local public buses, which cost 0.95 TL one-way.

Buses from
in the west take around 5 hours and cost 25 TL, while the service from
in the east takes 4 hours and also costs 25 TL.
was suspended in 2008 (and it is not certain when and if it will resume service), Turkish State Railways put a weekly passenger train service from Gaziantep to
recently, which crosses a short strip of
n territory. It departs from Mosul at noon every Tuesday and arrives in Gaziantep 5:40AM the next day, and costs €25 pp. (

value: Update, Aug 2010. Mosul service has been suspended until further notice.

)

There also twice weekly trains connecting the city to

. From Aleppo, trains depart at 5AM on Tuesdays and Fridays, arriving in Gaziantep five hours later. From Gaziantep, they depart at 8:30PM on Tuesdays and Fridays and arrive five hours later in Aleppo, at 1:29AM after midnight. The trip costs €12.75 pp one-way.
The city centre is reasonably compact and walkable. There are plenty of local buses if you prefer and of course taxis for tired feet.

value: directions=on the corner of Kamil Ocak Caddesi and İstasyon Caddesi; south of train station
content=This local archaeological museum, which also has a small cafe inside, is wheelchair accessible.

. It is a great opportunity to learn from the Turkish point of view what happened in the WWI, especially what concerns to the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire and the further occupation. 1 TL (0.50 TL for students). Even if the talk on national heroes might come off as a little too detailed and boring for non-Turks, the ultra-cheap admission fee is well worth for the view from the top of the castle.
directions=look for the hard-to-miss signposts around the castle
content=Interesting museum on traditional Turkish cuisine and tools used for food preparation.
content= Opened in 2011, Zeugma Museum hosts stunning mosaics excavated at the nearby
, a city of antiquity known for its pontoon bridge crossing the Euphrates, and is now submerged under the waters of the Birecik Dam.

Visit the castle, explore the bazaars and don't forget the museum. There are a lot of museums in the center of city, especially some of them are close to castle. You should go Mosaic Museum (close to stadium), Medusa Museum (Glass Museum), Martyr's Museum, Dervishes Museum (
You can buy a lot of traditional things in Gaziantep. You should try
, a traditional bazaar in the center of the city. You can buy

(local leather shoes) and much more...

As the centre of a large pistachio-growing region, as the groves along the highway leading to Gaziantep indicate, you can find many stores selling this local product (known in Turkish as
, i.e. "Pistachio of Antep", an expression which surpassed the former name of
", used during Ottoman period), both fresh (not very tasty, though) and also in a salty roasted variety (a lot more delicious!).
Antep is known for its cuisine that is heavily influenced by its
. The city is renowned for its local variety of kebab (
). You can find many places that sell spicy kebabs here. Make sure you enter a place that is crowded and order
, which is minced, marinated, spiced meat with minced vegetables on an extremely thin, crunchy dough.

can be made with garlic or onions, in general, you will find garlic ones in Antep.

Antep is also famous for its pistachios. You can find fresh, unroasted pistachios as well as roasted ones. Try the spicy nuts.

Upon finishing your dinner, make sure to have

made with pistachios. Also, you can try the hot desserts with a scoop of ice cream on top.

Antep is known for its food, and meals there are one of the highlights of visiting the region.  So enjoy yourself.
Many of Antep's drinking establishments are basically for picking up women. However there are some nice
s ("beer-houses") where you can enjoy a quiet drink in peace.

value: address=Bey Mah. Kayacık Sokak No 16, Şahinbey
directions=off Atatürk Boulevard, parallel to Hürriyet Caddesi behind the Post Office
price=35 TL/50 TL low/high season for a double room including breakfast
content=Two stars in city centre with very clean rooms and free Wi-Fi. Staff are exceptionally friendly, although there is not a lot of English.

content=It is a good hotel, in a perfect location. In February 2010, it was possible to bargain the price from the original 45 TL down to 35 TL, including the dinner and a very good breakfast. Obtaining the reduction will depend on the season, the manager, and the ability to bargain.
price=25 TL/45 TL low/high season a room with a double bed
content=Not the most sparkling of hotels, but absolutely acceptable and with a private bathroom, satellite TV and Wi-Fi.

price=100-140 TL, but bargainable down to 80 TL for a double room, including breakfast—make sure to bargain here and be careful when paying with a credit card so that you don't pay for drinks that you have not even seen the can or the bottle of

you will find numerous agents selling tickets to dozens of destinations including
to name a few. Buses leave frequently. Shop around for the best price.
